newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish zloty in bull run to parity - dealers.
newsitem.headline: Polish zloty in bull run to parity - dealers.

text.p: The Polish zloty firmed half a percentage point against the basket in early Friday trade and dealers said the local currency's bull run may push the unit back up toward parity within days, dealers said.

They said Thursday's central bank currency-selling intervention, which occured when the zloty slipped just below -1.5 percent from parity, created a strong bullish zloty sentiment on the market and sent the local unit soaring.
"Polish banks are selling-currencies and so are foreigners and the zloty could rise to zero (parity) within days," said Pawel Gajewski, forex dealer at Creditanstalt in Warsaw.
At 0755 GMT the zloty was -0.47/-0.66 percent from the parity rate, against opening's -1.21/-1.48 percent from parity and Thursday's close at -1.49/-1.55 percent.
It was at 3.4260/20 to the dollar, against 3.4510/00 at opening and at 1.8660/00 to the mark against 1.8800/50.
The OECD joined other international organisations in urging Poland to drastically tighten its fiscal policy to contain the fast growing current account deficit.
It said Poland should cut the budget gap to 1.5 perent of GDP in 1998 and balance the budget in 1999, while the finance ministry says a 1.9 percent gap in 1998 would be sufficient.
Some dealers said however that the zloty could be subject to some profit taking after rising some five percentage points from last week's all-time lows.
On the money market one-day rates eased as banks wanted to place cash on the market for the weekend, dealers said.
Overnight rates fell to 18.50/21.00 percent from opening's 21.00/21.20 percent and Thursday's 21.70/22.45. Tomorrow/next were at 21.00/22.50 percent, against Thursday's 22.00/22.35.
